qas.question: What does a T cell extend when it encounters a foreign pathogen?
What is the active form of vitamin D known as?
What is the nature of the relationship between T-cells and vitamin D?
What gene is responsible for converting calcidiol into calcitriol?
Other than T cells, what other immune cells express CYP27B1?
What does a pathogen do when it encounters a T-cell?
What cell binds to vitamin C?
What vitamin do T-cells have a parasitic relationship with?
What gene is expressed by the B-cell?
What gene converts calcitriol into calcidiol?

context: When a T-cell encounters a foreign pathogen, it <a0_1><b5_0>extends <a0_0>a <a0_2>vitamin D receptor<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. This is essentially a signaling device that allows the <b6_0>T-cell<b6_0/> to bind to the active form of vitamin D, the <a1_2>steroid hormone <a1_0><a1_1>calcitriol<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. T-cells have a <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>symbiotic<a2_1/> relationship<a2_2/><a2_0/> with <b7_0>vitamin D<b7_0/>. Not only does the T-cell extend a vitamin D receptor, in essence asking to bind to the steroid hormone version of vitamin D, calcitriol, but the T-cell expresses the <a3_0><a3_2>gene <a3_1><b8_0><b9_0>CYP27B1<b9_0/><b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, which is the gene responsible for converting the pre-hormone version of vitamin D, calcidiol into the steroid hormone version, calcitriol. Only after binding to calcitriol can T-cells perform their intended function. Other immune system cells that are known to express CYP27B1 and thus activate vitamin D calcidiol, are <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>dendritic cells<a4_2/>, keratinocytes and macrophages<a4_1/><a4_0/>.
